name: Cherry Tomato
description: Small, prolific tomatoes that ripen quickly and are perfect for snacking, salads, and containers. They produce hundreds of fruits per plant over a long season and are far more forgiving than larger tomato varieties.
tips: Pinch out laterals (side shoots) for bigger fruit. Stake or cage when 30 cm tall. Water consistently ‚Äî irregular watering causes blossom end rot. Feed with potassium-rich fertiliser once flowering starts.

name: Roma Tomato
description: A meaty, low-moisture paste tomato ideal for sauces, roasting, and drying. Roma types produce large, reliable crops and are more disease-resistant than many other tomatoes.
tips: Determinate varieties set all their fruit at once ‚Äî great for batch-preserving. Let fruit fully ripen on the vine for best flavour. Reduce watering as fruit matures to concentrate sweetness.

name: Beefsteak Tomato
description: Large, meaty tomatoes weighing up to 500 g each, with a rich flavour perfect for slicing and sandwiches. They need more space and care than cherry types but the reward is spectacular.
tips: Remove all but 1‚Äì2 main stems for the largest fruit. Feed heavily with a tomato fertiliser every 2 weeks once fruiting begins. Support each fruit truss with a clip or soft tie.

name: Capsicum
description: Sweet bell peppers that change from green to red, yellow, or orange as they ripen. They love hot summers and produce abundantly in warm Australian climates.
tips: Need warm soil ‚Äî don't rush transplanting. Pick green capsicums early to encourage more fruit, or leave them to fully colour for sweeter flavour. Feed with a potassium-rich fertiliser once flowering.

name: Chilli (Mild)
description: Mild to medium chillies including jalape√±o, cayenne, and banana pepper, delivering flavour and gentle heat to cooking. They are prolific producers that dry and freeze beautifully.
tips: In frost-free climates, chilli plants can live for years ‚Äî cut back hard in autumn and they regrow vigorously. Stress the plant slightly by reducing water once fruiting to increase heat level.

name: Chilli (Hot)
description: Fiery chillies including habanero, bird's eye, and Carolina Reaper, suited to the heat of Australian summers. They need a long, warm growing season and reward patience with intense harvests.
tips: Start seeds in a warm spot ‚Äî a heat mat speeds germination significantly for hot varieties. Can take longer to produce ripe fruit than mild chillies. Wear gloves when handling super-hot varieties.

name: Eggplant
description: Also called aubergine, eggplant produces glossy purple (or white, or striped) fruit beloved in Mediterranean and Asian cooking. It thrives in Australia's hot summers and is beautiful enough for ornamental gardens.
tips: Needs heat to thrive ‚Äî don't rush planting out. Harvest when skin is glossy; dull skin means it's overripe and bitter. Stake plants as they become top-heavy with fruit.

name: Zucchini
description: One of the most productive vegetables in the home garden ‚Äî a single plant can produce dozens of zucchinis per season. Harvest young for the best flavour and texture; oversized zucchinis become watery and seedy.
tips: Hand-pollinate flowers if you see fruit failing to set ‚Äî use a paintbrush to transfer pollen from male to female flowers (female flowers have a tiny zucchini behind the flower). Harvest at 15‚Äì20 cm for best flavour.

name: Lebanese Cucumber
description: Thin-skinned, crisp cucumbers with few seeds and a mild flavour ‚Äî the most popular home garden cucumber in Australia. They climb readily and are excellent for containers with a trellis.
tips: Water at the base ‚Äî wet foliage encourages powdery mildew. Pick regularly; leaving cucumbers to yellow on the vine signals the plant to stop producing. Feed weekly once fruiting.

name: Butternut Pumpkin
description: A sweet, nutty pumpkin with smooth tan skin and rich orange flesh that stores for months. Butternut is one of the most popular cooking pumpkins in Australia and stores well through autumn and winter.
tips: Allow vines to sprawl ‚Äî they need a lot of space. Harvest when the skin is hard and the stem has dried and corked over. Cure in a warm, dry spot for 2 weeks before storing to harden the skin.

name: Kent Pumpkin
description: Also called Jap pumpkin, Kent is the most versatile cooking pumpkin in Australia with sweet, dry flesh perfect for roasting, soups, and curries. Large, ribbed, dark green fruit with an orange-yellow interior.
tips: Plant in a mound of rich compost. Allow the fruit to fully mature on the vine ‚Äî check by pressing a fingernail into the skin; if it doesn't dent, it's ready. Store in a cool, dry place for up to 6 months.

name: Sweet Corn
description: Nothing beats fresh corn picked and cooked within minutes ‚Äî the sugars convert to starch rapidly after harvest. Grow in a block (not a row) for good pollination and a satisfying summer harvest.
tips: Plant in a block of at least 4√ó4 plants for wind pollination. Test for ripeness by pressing a kernel ‚Äî it should ooze milky liquid. Harvest in the cool of morning and cook immediately for sweetest flavour.

name: Okra
description: A tall, beautiful plant producing ribbed green pods used in stews, curries, and stir-fries. Okra loves heat and is perfectly suited to Australia's hot summers; it struggles in cool climates.
tips: Soak seeds overnight to improve germination. Harvest pods when 7‚Äì10 cm long ‚Äî larger pods become tough and fibrous. Pick every 2‚Äì3 days to keep the plant producing.

name: Cos Lettuce
description: Also called Romaine, cos lettuce forms tall, upright heads with crisp, dark green leaves and a crunchy midrib. It is more heat-tolerant than other lettuces and is the classic choice for Caesar salad.
tips: Cut the outer leaves rather than the whole head for a continuous harvest. In summer, provide afternoon shade to delay bolting (going to seed). Sow every 3‚Äì4 weeks for a continuous supply.

name: Butter Lettuce
description: A soft-headed lettuce with tender, buttery leaves and a mild, delicate flavour. Butter lettuce is less heat-tolerant than cos varieties and is best grown in the cooler months in most of Australia.
tips: Water at the base to keep leaves dry and prevent rot. Harvest the whole head when it feels firm, or pick outer leaves for a cut-and-come-again approach. Best flavour in cool weather.

name: Loose-leaf Lettuce
description: Non-heading lettuce varieties including oak leaf, coral, and mignonette that can be harvested leaf by leaf for months. The most versatile and productive lettuce type for Australian home gardens.
tips: Scatter seeds thinly and thin to 20 cm apart. Harvest outer leaves once the plant has 6‚Äì8 leaves. Succession-sow every 3 weeks for a continuous supply. Red varieties have better heat tolerance.

name: Spinach
description: Nutritious, fast-growing leafy green rich in iron, folate, and antioxidants. Spinach prefers cool weather and bolts quickly in heat ‚Äî grow it in autumn, winter, and early spring for best results.
tips: Direct sow is best ‚Äî spinach doesn't like transplanting. Harvest outer leaves when 10 cm long. As weather warms, harvest the whole plant before it bolts. Soak seeds for a few hours before planting to speed germination.

name: Silverbeet
description: Also known as Swiss chard, silverbeet is one of the most productive and reliable vegetables for Australian gardens, producing large, glossy leaves with colourful stems almost year-round. It handles both heat and light frosts.
tips: Each seed cluster produces multiple seedlings ‚Äî thin to one plant. Harvest outer leaves from the base. Remove any leaves showing signs of yellow or disease promptly. Rainbow silverbeet varieties have colourful stems and are ornamental as well as edible.

name: Tuscan Kale
description: Also called cavolo nero or dinosaur kale, this Italian heirloom has long, dark, crinkled leaves with an earthy, savoury flavour that improves after frost. It is a beautiful and productive cool-season green.
tips: Harvest the lower leaves first, leaving the growing crown intact for months of continued harvest. Massage raw leaves with a little oil and salt to tenderise them for salads. Flavour improves significantly after a light frost.

name: Curly Kale
description: The classic, tightly curled kale with a robust, slightly bitter flavour and exceptional nutritional density. Very cold-hardy and one of the easiest brassicas to grow in Australian cool-season gardens.
tips: Pick outer leaves from the base upward. Curly kale holds up well to long cooking and is great in soups and colcannon. Apply netting to protect from cabbage white butterfly.

name: Rocket
description: A peppery, nutty salad leaf that is one of the fastest vegetables to harvest from seed. Rocket grows almost year-round in Australia and is excellent for containers, edges, and cut-and-come-again growing.
tips: Direct sow ‚Äî dislikes transplanting. Scatter seed thinly and cover lightly. Harvest once leaves are 8‚Äì10 cm. Hot weather triggers bolting and extreme bitterness; shade or harvest early in summer. Succession sow every 3 weeks.

name: Bok Choy
description: A crisp, mild Asian green with tender white stems and dark glossy leaves, ready in as little as 6 weeks. Bok choy is excellent stir-fried, steamed, or eaten raw and grows happily in pots.
tips: Keep soil consistently moist ‚Äî drought stress triggers bolting. Harvest baby bok choy at 15 cm for the tenderest leaves, or let it grow to full size. Protect from caterpillars with fine netting.

name: Tatsoi
description: A flat, rosette-forming Asian green with dark, spoon-shaped leaves and a mild, slightly mustardy flavour. Extremely cold-hardy and one of the best brassicas for winter gardens in temperate Australia.
tips: One of the last greens standing in winter. Pick outer leaves to extend harvest. Excellent for microgreens and baby leaf mix. Bolt-resistant compared to other brassica greens.

name: Mizuna
description: A feathery, mildly peppery Japanese salad green with deeply serrated, bright green leaves. Mizuna is incredibly versatile ‚Äî eaten raw in salads, lightly wilted in stir-fries, or added to soups.
tips: Cut and come again ‚Äî harvest the outer leaves 4‚Äì5 cm above the base and the plant regrows repeatedly. Blend in salad mixes to add a mild peppery bite. More heat-tolerant than many Asian greens.

name: Watercress
description: A peppery, nutrient-dense aquatic green traditionally grown in streams but equally at home in a consistently moist pot or trough. Excellent in salads and soups and one of the most nutritious vegetables you can grow.
tips: Keep the root zone consistently wet ‚Äî stand the pot in a tray of water. Harvest tops regularly to prevent flowering and keep flavour mild. Bolts in heat and drought; best in a shaded, moist spot.

name: Radicchio
description: A striking Italian chicory with burgundy-red and white leaves and a pleasantly bitter flavour that mellows with cooking. Radicchio is excellent grilled, braised, or in autumn salads.
tips: Colour and heads develop best in cool autumn weather. You can cut the plant back to 3 cm above the soil and it will regrow a new, tighter head. Expose to light frost to sweeten the flavour.

name: Broccoli
description: A cool-season brassica producing dense green heads rich in vitamins C and K. After cutting the main head, most varieties produce smaller side shoots for weeks, extending the harvest significantly.
tips: Harvest the main head before any yellow flowers open. After the main head is cut, continue watering and feeding ‚Äî side shoots will develop for another 4‚Äì6 weeks. Net against cabbage white butterfly.

name: Cauliflower
description: One of the most demanding cool-season vegetables, but deeply rewarding when its creamy white curds develop to perfection. Cauliflower needs consistently cool temperatures and rich, moist soil.
tips: Blanch the curd by folding outer leaves over it and securing ‚Äî this keeps it white and prevents bitterness. Harvest before the curd begins to separate or discolour. Heat stress causes irregular, ricey curds.

name: Green Cabbage
description: A staple cool-season vegetable producing dense, round heads used raw in coleslaw, fermented into sauerkraut, or cooked in soups and stir-fries. Cabbage stores well in a cool place after harvest.
tips: Net from day one to prevent cabbage white butterfly damage. Firm soil well around the base. When the head is solid and feels firm when pressed, it's ready ‚Äî don't leave it too long or it may split after rain.

name: Brussels Sprouts
description: Tiny, cabbage-like sprouts that grow in rows up a tall stalk and develop their best flavour after frost. Brussels sprouts require the longest growing season of any brassica but are deeply satisfying to harvest.
tips: Stake plants as they grow tall and top-heavy. Remove yellowing lower leaves as sprouts develop. Harvest from the bottom up as lower sprouts mature first. Flavour improves dramatically after the first frost.

name: Kohlrabi
description: An unusual brassica that forms a swollen, turnip-like stem above the ground with a mild, crisp, slightly sweet flavour ‚Äî halfway between broccoli stem and apple. Excellent eaten raw, roasted, or in slaws.
tips: Harvest when the bulb is tennis-ball sized ‚Äî waiting too long makes it woody. The leaves are edible too, similar to kale. One of the easier brassicas for beginners because it's less bothered by pests.

name: Carrot
description: A versatile root vegetable available in orange, purple, yellow, and white varieties, with a sweet, earthy flavour that intensifies with cold. Carrots are direct-sown and are excellent in containers with deep pots.
tips: Direct sow only ‚Äî do not transplant. Soil must be fine, stone-free, and deeply cultivated; compacted or stony soil causes forked roots. Mix seed with sand to sow thinly. Keep soil moist until germination (can take 2‚Äì3 weeks). Thin to 8 cm apart.

name: Beetroot
description: A dual-purpose vegetable where both the sweet, earthy roots and the nutritious leaves are edible. Beetroot is one of the most flexible vegetables in Australian gardens, growing in almost every season.
tips: Each seed cluster produces 2‚Äì3 seedlings ‚Äî thin to one after germination. Harvest when roots are golf-ball to tennis-ball size for best flavour. Twist the tops off rather than cutting to prevent 'bleeding'.

name: Parsnip
description: A sweet, nutty root vegetable that develops its best flavour after cold nights convert starches to sugar. Parsnips take patience ‚Äî they have a long growing season ‚Äî but are among the most rewarding winter vegetables.
tips: Use fresh seed every year ‚Äî parsnip seeds lose viability quickly. Germination is slow and irregular; sow thickly and be patient. Flavour is best after the first autumn frost. Deep, stone-free soil prevents forked roots.

name: Radish
description: The fastest vegetable you can grow ‚Äî some varieties are ready in as little as 3 weeks from seed. Radishes are perfect for impatient gardeners, for gap-filling between slower crops, and for teaching children to garden.
tips: Sow direct and thin ‚Äî they really don't need much care. Harvest promptly when roots are 2‚Äì3 cm as they become pithy and hollow quickly after maturity. Succession-sow every 2‚Äì3 weeks for a continuous supply.
common_problems: Pithy roots from waiting too long

name: Daikon Radish
description: A large, white Japanese radish up to 40 cm long with a milder, more complex flavour than small radishes. Used grated raw, pickled, or braised in Asian cuisines, and also excellent as a soil-breaking green manure.
tips: Requires deep, loose soil for the long roots to develop properly. Sow direct ‚Äî transplanting is not suitable. Harvest before roots become pithy and woody. Leaves are edible and delicious stir-fried.

name: Turnip
description: A fast-growing cool-season root with a crisp, mildly peppery flavour when harvested young and small. The tops (turnip greens) are also nutritious and delicious saut√©ed or added to soups.
tips: Harvest when roots are 5‚Äì7 cm ‚Äî they're sweetest when small. Larger roots become tough, woody, and strong-flavoured. The greens are best harvested young as a bonus crop before the root is ready.

name: Sweet Potato
description: A vigorous warm-season vine grown from slips (rooted cuttings) that produces sweet, orange-fleshed tubers. Sweet potatoes love heat and are extremely productive in warm Australian climates once established.
tips: Grow from slips, not seeds. Let the vines sprawl ‚Äî they can cover a large area. Harvest after 3‚Äì5 months when the leaves start to yellow. Cure in a warm, dry spot for 2 weeks to improve sweetness and storage life.

name: Potato
description: The world's most popular vegetable, grown from seed potatoes (small tubers) rather than seeds. Potatoes are surprisingly easy to grow in garden beds, raised beds, or even large bags and bins.
tips: Buy certified seed potatoes to avoid disease. 'Earth up' (mound soil around stems as they grow) to increase yield and prevent greening. Harvest after plants flower and tops begin to die back. New potatoes can be dug earlier for a tender, waxy treat.

name: Celeriac
description: A knobbly, turnip-like root with a rich celery flavour, excellent roasted, mashed, or used raw in remoulade. It requires a long growing season and consistent moisture but is deeply rewarding.
tips: Start seeds indoors 10‚Äì12 weeks before transplanting. Keep soil consistently moist throughout the growing season. Remove outer stems in late summer to expose the swelling root to more sun.

name: Brown Onion
description: The everyday kitchen staple with papery brown skin and pungent white flesh. Brown onions take patience ‚Äî about 6 months from seed ‚Äî but are simple to grow and store well for months after curing.
tips: Harvest when tops fall over naturally. Cure in a warm, dry, airy spot for 2‚Äì3 weeks ‚Äî do not wash ‚Äî until the necks are completely dry. Properly cured onions store for 6‚Äì12 months. Can also be grown from sets (small bulbs) for faster results.

name: Red Onion
description: Milder and sweeter than brown onions with striking purple-red skin. Red onions are excellent raw in salads, pickled, or caramelised and contain high levels of anthocyanin antioxidants.
tips: Same care as brown onions. Red onions may not store quite as long as brown onions ‚Äî use within 3‚Äì6 months. Flavour is milder and sweeter when grown in cooler weather.

name: Spring Onion
description: Slender, mild-flavoured onions harvested whole ‚Äî both the white base and green tops are edible. One of the easiest and fastest alliums, ready in 8‚Äì12 weeks and excellent in containers.
tips: Sow thickly in clumps or rows. Snip the green tops at any time ‚Äî they will regrow. Harvest whole plants when 30‚Äì40 cm. Succession sow every 3 weeks for a non-stop supply. Can be grown on a sunny kitchen windowsill.

name: Leek
description: A mild, sweet member of the onion family with a long white shaft and dark green leaves. Leeks are a key ingredient in soups and slow-cooked dishes and are one of the most cold-hardy vegetables available.
tips: Transplant seedlings into 15 cm deep holes and let them fill naturally ‚Äî this creates a long, blanched white shaft. Hill up soil around stems as they grow to extend the white section. Harvest at any size, from pencil to thumb-thick.

name: Garlic
description: The world's most used flavouring, grown from individual cloves planted in autumn for a late spring/summer harvest. Each clove you plant becomes a whole bulb ‚Äî a magical and satisfying crop for any garden.
tips: Plant cloves with the pointed end up, 5 cm deep. Stop watering when tops begin to yellow and die back. Harvest before all leaves die ‚Äî leave 4‚Äì5 green leaves so the bulb wraps properly. Cure in a warm, dry spot with good airflow for 3‚Äì4 weeks.

name: Elephant Garlic
description: Despite its name, elephant garlic is actually a type of leek, producing very large bulbs with a much milder, sweeter flavour than true garlic. The huge cloves are easy to peel and excellent roasted whole.
tips: Plant cloves deeper than regular garlic. May produce single-clove 'rounds' in the first year ‚Äî replant these for a full bulb the next season. Smaller yield per clove but stunning visual presence in the garden.

name: Shallot
description: Small, elongated onions with a delicate, complex flavour prized in fine cooking. Each bulb multiplies into a cluster of 4‚Äì8 bulbs ‚Äî plant one, harvest many. Excellent stored and keeps very well.
tips: Plant the bulb with the tip just showing above the soil surface. Harvest when tops have died back and dry. Save some bulbs each year to replant ‚Äî shallots can be self-perpetuating if you always keep some back.

name: Chives
description: A perennial herb forming clumps of hollow, grass-like leaves with a mild onion flavour and pretty purple flowers in spring. Chives are one of the lowest-maintenance herbs you can grow ‚Äî snip and it regrows endlessly.
tips: Cut back hard every few months to encourage fresh growth. The purple flowers are edible and beautiful in salads. Divide clumps every few years to keep them vigorous. Dies back somewhat in winter but returns strongly in spring.

name: Rockmelon
description: Also called cantaloupe, rockmelon produces fragrant, orange-fleshed fruit with a netted skin and exceptional sweetness. It needs a long, hot summer and warm nights to develop properly ‚Äî ideal for Australian conditions.
tips: Reduce watering as fruit matures to concentrate sugars. Ripe rockmelon slips easily from the vine with slight pressure. A yellowing skin base and sweet fragrance are signs of ripeness. Limit to 3‚Äì4 fruit per plant for best size.

name: Watermelon
description: A quintessential summer fruit requiring heat, space, and a long growing season to produce its large, sweet, juicy fruit. Australia's hot summers are ideal watermelon-growing conditions.
tips: Choose a compact or 'icebox' variety for smaller gardens. Test for ripeness by tapping ‚Äî a ripe watermelon sounds hollow rather than solid. The tendril nearest the fruit dries and curls when it's ready. Reduce water the last 2 weeks for sweeter fruit.

name: Celery
description: A crunchy, aromatic vegetable that demands consistently moist, rich soil and is one of the more challenging vegetables to grow well. The reward is crisp stalks with a complexity far superior to supermarket celery.
tips: Surface sow seeds (they need light to germinate) and keep moist. Transplant carefully at 10 cm. Keep soil consistently moist ‚Äî any drying out causes stringy, bitter stalks. Cut outer stalks as needed and let the centre continue growing.

name: Asparagus
description: A long-lived perennial that takes 3 years to produce its first proper harvest but then delivers tender spears every spring for 20+ years. Establishing an asparagus bed is a gift to your future gardening self.
tips: Plant crowns rather than seeds to save a year. Do not harvest at all in years 1‚Äì2 ‚Äî let the fern develop to build a strong root system. In year 3, harvest for 4‚Äì6 weeks only. Let plants fern out after harvest to store energy for next year.

name: Globe Artichoke
description: A dramatic, architectural perennial that produces large, edible flower buds with sweet, nutty hearts much prized in Mediterranean cooking. Plants live for 5‚Äì8 years and become more productive each year.
tips: Harvest the main central bud first when scales are still tight. Side buds will then develop. Cut plants back to 30 cm after harvest and fertilise well. Divide and replant offsets every 4‚Äì5 years to rejuvenate.

name: Fennel (Bulb)
description: A crisp, sweet vegetable with a delicate anise flavour, prized in Italian cooking. The swollen white base is eaten raw or cooked, while the feathery fronds are used as an herb. Different from the herb fennel grown just for seeds.
tips: Fennel is allelopathic ‚Äî it inhibits growth of many vegetables. Keep it isolated or at the garden edge. Hill soil around the base to blanch the bulb and keep it tender. Harvest when the base is 8‚Äì10 cm across.

name: Rhubarb
description: A tart, vigorously growing perennial grown for its ruby-red stalks used in crumbles, jams, and pies. Rhubarb is extremely long-lived and low-maintenance once established ‚Äî the leaves are poisonous, only stalks are eaten.
tips: Plant crowns rather than seeds for faster establishment. Do not harvest in the first year. In year 2 take only 2‚Äì3 stalks. From year 3 you can harvest freely. Remove flower stalks immediately ‚Äî they divert energy from the crown. NEVER eat the leaves.

name: Basil (Sweet)
description: The fragrant, sweet herb at the heart of Italian cooking and the perfect companion plant for tomatoes. Basil is frost-sensitive and absolutely thrives in Australian summers, growing prolifically in warm weather.
tips: Pinch out flower buds as soon as they appear to keep leaves coming and prevent bitterness. Harvest from the top, taking full stems just above a leaf node. Never expose to cold ‚Äî even a cold draught can blacken leaves. Grow near a warm wall for best results.

name: Basil (Thai)
description: A more heat-tolerant basil with a complex anise and clove scent, purple stems, and glossy leaves. Indispensable in Thai, Vietnamese, and other South-East Asian cuisines and holds up better than sweet basil when cooked.
tips: More resilient in heat and humidity than sweet basil. Allow some plants to flower ‚Äî the flowers and buds are also edible and beautiful. Can be propagated easily from cuttings in a glass of water.

name: Parsley (Flat-leaf)
description: The preferred parsley of most chefs, with a brighter, more complex flavour than curly parsley. It's packed with vitamin C and K and is far more versatile as both a garnish and a cooking ingredient.
tips: Parsley is famously slow to germinate ‚Äî up to 3 weeks. Soak seeds overnight to speed things up. Harvest outer stems from the base. In year 2 it will flower and set seed; collect seeds and remove the plant as it dies after seeding.

name: Parsley (Curly)
description: The classic garnish parsley with tightly curled, bright green leaves and a milder flavour than flat-leaf varieties. Hardy and prolific, curly parsley is an excellent beginner herb that produces abundantly.
tips: Same care as flat-leaf parsley. The tightly curled leaves trap water ‚Äî water at the base to prevent fungal issues. Both types can be dried or frozen for long-term storage. Excellent pot companion for ornamental gardens.

name: Coriander
description: An essential herb in Asian, Middle Eastern, and Latin cooking, with both the leaves (called coriander or cilantro) and the dried seeds used. Notoriously prone to bolting in heat ‚Äî it is a cool-season herb at heart.
tips: Direct sow ‚Äî dislikes transplanting. Sow thickly in partial shade in warmer months. Harvest whole stems from the base before flowers appear. When it bolts, let it set seed ‚Äî the dried seeds are a spice in themselves. Succession sow every 3‚Äì4 weeks.

name: Dill
description: A tall, feathery herb with a distinctive fresh flavour used in pickles, fish dishes, salads, and dips. Both the leaves (dill weed) and seeds are used, making every part of the plant valuable.
tips: Direct sow ‚Äî does not like transplanting. Harvest leaves before flowers develop. Let some plants go to seed ‚Äî the seeds can be saved for cooking or for next year's crop. Self-seeds readily, so you may find it returning year after year.

name: Spearmint
description: The most common garden mint with a bright, refreshing flavour used in everything from teas and cocktails to salads and lamb dishes. Highly vigorous ‚Äî grow in a pot to prevent it taking over the entire garden.
tips: ALWAYS grow in a container ‚Äî mint spreads aggressively via underground runners and will colonise your whole garden if left unchecked. Harvest stems from the top, leaving lower leaves. Cut back hard in late summer to encourage fresh growth.

name: Peppermint
description: A naturally occurring hybrid mint with intense menthol flavour and a cool, refreshing finish. Used in teas, desserts, and digestive remedies. Like all mints, it spreads aggressively and is best contained.
tips: Best propagated from cuttings or divisions rather than seed. Grow in a buried pot to contain roots. Harvest before flowering for the strongest flavour. Dries beautifully ‚Äî hang bunches upside down in a warm, airy spot.

name: Rosemary
description: A woody, aromatic Mediterranean shrub with needle-like leaves and a warm, piney, resinous flavour. Rosemary thrives on neglect ‚Äî it's drought-tolerant, frost-hardy in most of Australia, and can live for decades.
tips: Easier to grow from a cutting or nursery plant than from seed. Excellent drainage is critical ‚Äî rosemary hates wet feet and will rot in heavy, waterlogged soil. Trim lightly after flowering to keep shape. Prune hard in spring to rejuvenate old woody plants.

name: Thyme
description: A low-growing, woody perennial with tiny aromatic leaves and a warm, earthy flavour essential in French and Mediterranean cooking. One of the most versatile culinary herbs and perfect for edging paths and containers.
tips: Excellent drainage is essential. Harvest before or during flowering for strongest flavour. Cut back by a third after flowering to prevent the plant becoming too woody. Good drainage and full sun are more important than fertile soil.

name: Lemon Thyme
description: A charming hybrid thyme with a pronounced citrus-lemon fragrance alongside the classic thyme warmth. Beautiful variegated varieties exist and make excellent low-maintenance garden edging or pot plants.
tips: Best propagated from cuttings. Excellent with fish, chicken, and in salad dressings where its lemony brightness shines. Care is identical to common thyme.

name: Oregano
description: The pungent, earthy herb synonymous with pizza and pasta sauces. Greek oregano is the most intensely flavoured variety ‚Äî the more sun and poor soil it gets, the more aromatic it becomes.
tips: Harvest just before flowering for peak flavour. Grows best in lean, well-drained soil ‚Äî too much fertiliser reduces the essential oil content and flavour. Dry bunches easily; dried oregano is more pungent than fresh.

name: Sage
description: A beautiful, velvety-leaved perennial with a warm, musky flavour essential in stuffings, butter sauces, and with pork and chicken dishes. Sage is also highly ornamental with purple or white flowers in spring.
tips: Trim hard after flowering to prevent it becoming straggly. Replace plants every 4‚Äì5 years when they become very woody. Ornamental coloured-leaf varieties (purple, tricolour) are just as edible as plain green types.

name: Lemongrass
description: A tall, tropical grass with a fresh, citrusy fragrance used extensively in Thai, Vietnamese, and South-East Asian cooking. Lemongrass thrives in warm Australian climates and grows into a dramatic clump in a large pot.
tips: Buy a pot from a grocery store or nursery and divide ‚Äî far easier than growing from seed. Harvest outer stalks by cutting at the base. Bring indoors or protect from frost in cool-winter areas. Divides easily into new clumps every 2‚Äì3 years.

name: Vietnamese Mint
description: Also called rau ram or hot mint, this is not a true mint but has a pungent, lemony, peppery flavour used in Vietnamese salads, spring rolls, and soups. Vigorous and productive in warm climates.
tips: Propagate from cuttings ‚Äî place a stem in water and roots appear in days. More heat-tolerant than common mint. Keep consistently moist. Best flavour in warm weather; growth slows in winter but plant survives.

name: Tarragon (French)
description: The king of French herb cooking with a distinctive, sophisticated anise flavour essential in b√©arnaise sauce, fines herbes, and with chicken and fish. French tarragon cannot be grown from seed ‚Äî only from divisions or cuttings.
tips: Buy only FRENCH tarragon ‚Äî Russian tarragon (often sold from seed) has almost no flavour. Dies back in winter and resprouts strongly in spring. Divide every 3 years to keep vigorous. Excellent drainage is essential.
common_problems: False Russian tarragon sold as French

name: Marjoram
description: A close relative of oregano with a sweeter, more delicate and floral flavour. Marjoram is excellent with eggs, vegetables, and lamb and is widely used in European cooking. More tender than oregano.
tips: Harvest before flowering for best flavour. Trim regularly to keep it from becoming leggy. Less cold-hardy than oregano ‚Äî protect in areas with hard frosts. Excellent for drying.

name: Bay Leaf
description: A slow-growing Mediterranean tree or large shrub whose aromatic leaves are used to flavour soups, stews, stocks, and sauces. Bay is an outstanding container plant that can be clipped into formal shapes.
tips: Buy from a nursery rather than growing from seed. Slow to establish but essentially maintenance-free once settled. Pick leaves fresh as needed ‚Äî dry leaves on a flat surface in a warm room. In pots, pot up to the next size every 2‚Äì3 years.

name: Chamomile
description: A delicate, apple-scented herb with daisy-like flowers used to make the world's most popular herbal tea. German chamomile is grown as an annual and self-seeds abundantly; Roman chamomile is a perennial groundcover.
tips: Surface sow ‚Äî seeds need light to germinate. Harvest flowers when they're fully open for tea, picking in the morning after the dew dries. Dry on a flat screen in a warm, dark place. Self-seeds prolifically once established.

name: Lemon Verbena
description: A semi-deciduous shrub with the most intensely lemon-scented leaves of any plant. Excellent for teas, desserts, cocktails, and marinades. One of the most rewarding scented plants for warm Australian gardens.
tips: Buy from a nursery. Prune hard in late winter before new growth appears. In cooler climates, it may drop its leaves in winter ‚Äî this is normal, not death. Protect from frost in cold areas. Leaves retain fragrance extremely well when dried.

name: Stevia
description: A South American herb whose leaves are 200‚Äì300 times sweeter than sugar, used as a natural zero-calorie sweetener. The leaves can be used fresh, dried, or made into a liquid extract for sweetening drinks and cooking.
tips: Harvest before flowering for sweetest leaves. Can be grown as a perennial in frost-free areas or as an annual elsewhere. Sweetness is highest when the plant is about to flower ‚Äî harvest the whole stem and dry or use fresh.

name: French Bean
description: Compact bush beans producing tender green pods 8‚Äì10 weeks from sowing. One of the most productive, low-maintenance vegetables in the garden ‚Äî direct sow and they practically grow themselves.
tips: Direct sow ‚Äî dislikes transplanting. Don't plant until soil is warm (above 15¬∞C). Pick pods regularly ‚Äî daily in peak season ‚Äî as leaving beans on the plant signals it to stop producing. Succession sow every 3 weeks.

name: Runner Bean
description: A vigorous climbing bean with striking scarlet flowers that are as ornamental as they are productive. Runner beans produce large, flat pods over a very long season and are often the most abundant legume in the garden.
tips: Needs a strong trellis ‚Äî these plants are heavy! Mist flowers during very hot weather to aid pollination. Pick young and tender ‚Äî older pods become stringy. Can survive winter in frost-free areas, regrowing from the tuber.

name: Broad Bean
description: A cool-season legume producing large, sweet beans inside velvety pods ‚Äî completely different in character from summer beans. Broad beans fix nitrogen in the soil and are an excellent green manure crop as well as a delicious food.
tips: Pinch out the growing tip when the first pods appear ‚Äî this improves yield and deters blackfly. Stake plants against wind. Harvest pods when firm but before the beans inside have hardened. Young leaves and flowers are also edible.

name: Snow Pea
description: Flat, tender pea pods eaten whole ‚Äî both pod and peas inside. Snow peas are the most popular pea variety in Australia, loved in stir-fries and eaten raw as a snack. They climb readily and are excellent for trellises.
tips: Direct sow ‚Äî dislikes transplanting. Provide support from the day of sowing ‚Äî pea tendrils grab immediately. Harvest pods while still flat, before peas swell inside. Pick regularly to keep plants producing.

name: Sugar Snap Pea
description: Plump, round pods eaten whole with juicy, sweet peas inside ‚Äî the most succulent fresh pea. Sugar snap peas are excellent eaten raw, lightly steamed, or quickly stir-fried and are incredibly popular with children.
tips: Wait until pods feel plump and rounded before picking ‚Äî this is when sweetness peaks. Like snow peas but allowed to fill out more. Eat within hours of picking for best flavour as sugars convert to starch rapidly.

name: Garden Pea
description: Traditional shelling peas where the outer pod is discarded and the sweet, tender peas inside are eaten. Garden peas are classic, sweet, and delicious ‚Äî nothing tastes quite like peas eaten straight from the pod.
tips: Sow thickly ‚Äî peas support each other. Pick when pods are full and rounded but before they become tough. Frozen immediately after picking, home-grown peas are far superior to commercial frozen peas. Great companion plant that fixes nitrogen.

name: Edamame
description: Young, green soybeans harvested before they mature, eaten boiled or steamed in their pods as a snack or in salads. Edamame is gaining popularity in Australian home gardens for its high protein content and delicious nutty flavour.
tips: Harvest when pods are plump and bright green but before they start to yellow. Steam immediately after harvest ‚Äî the sweetness fades quickly. One plant produces only a small number of pods so grow in a batch of 10+ plants.

name: Chickpea
description: The legume behind hummus, dahls, and countless Middle Eastern and Indian dishes. Chickpeas are a cool-season crop that thrives in dry conditions and is surprisingly easy to grow in Australian gardens.
tips: Direct sow in cool weather. Each plant produces a modest number of pods with 1‚Äì2 chickpeas each ‚Äî grow 20+ plants for a worthwhile harvest. Harvest pods when they turn tan and papery. Leave pods on the plant to dry fully before shelling for storage.

name: Borlotti Bean
description: A beautiful climbing bean with mottled pink-and-cream pods and creamy, earthy beans beloved in Italian cooking ‚Äî ribollita, pasta e fagioli, and stews. Can be eaten fresh or dried for storage.
tips: Harvest fresh when pods are plump for eating immediately. Let pods dry on the plant to shell and store as dried beans for the pantry. Stunning ornamental pods make them a dual-purpose edible and decorative plant.

name: Strawberry
description: The quintessential home garden fruit ‚Äî sweet, aromatic, and incomparably better fresh from the garden than anything available in a shop. Strawberries are perfect for containers, hanging baskets, and balconies.
tips: Plant runners or crowns in autumn for a spring/summer harvest. Remove runners in the first year to build plant strength. Mulch heavily to keep fruit off the soil and retain moisture. Replace plants every 3 years as productivity declines. Cover with netting before fruit ripens ‚Äî birds love them.

name: Raspberry
description: Fragrant, jewel-like berries on thorny canes that produce abundantly each summer once established. Raspberries require a proper cold winter to fruit well and are most productive in cooler parts of Australia.
tips: Plant bare-root canes in winter. Tie canes to a wire support system. After harvest, cut out the old canes that have fruited and tie in the new ones for next year. Primocane (autumn-fruiting) varieties also fruit on new season canes in autumn.

name: Blueberry
description: Nutritious, antioxidant-rich berries on attractive deciduous shrubs that turn brilliant red in autumn. Blueberries need acidic soil (pH 4.5‚Äì5.5) but are well-suited to container growing with the right potting mix.
tips: Must have acidic soil ‚Äî use azalea/camellia potting mix in containers. Plant at least 2 different varieties for cross-pollination and bigger harvests. Takes 3 years to reach full production. Mulch deeply with pine bark to maintain soil acidity.

name: Blackberry
description: Large, deeply flavoured berries on vigorous thorny canes that produce abundantly in summer. Thornless varieties are available and are highly recommended for smaller gardens or family gardens with children.
tips: Choose thornless varieties for easier management. Train canes along a wire trellis. Cut out old fruited canes to the ground after harvest. Note: wild blackberries are a declared weed in many parts of Australia ‚Äî choose cultivated varieties only.

name: Passionfruit
description: A fast-growing, self-fertile vine producing fragrant, intensely flavoured fruit that is uniquely Australian in its culinary popularity. Passionfruit grows with extraordinary vigour in warm to tropical climates.
tips: Buy a grafted plant from a nursery for best performance and disease resistance. Needs a very strong trellis ‚Äî the vine becomes extremely heavy. Harvest fruit when it falls or is easily twisted off ‚Äî wrinkled skin means fully ripe. Feed monthly with potassium-rich fertiliser when fruiting.

name: Grape (Table)
description: Deciduous vines producing clusters of sweet, juicy grapes in late summer and autumn. Grapes need a cold winter dormancy to produce well and are ideal for covering a pergola or fence while providing delicious fruit.
tips: Prune hard each winter to 2‚Äì3 buds per spur ‚Äî this is where next year's fruit grows. Thin grape clusters early in the season for larger, better-quality fruit. Choose table varieties over wine varieties for home use (sweeter, seedless options available).

name: Cape Gooseberry
description: A South American fruit producing golden berries wrapped in papery husks with a tangy, tropical, honey-like flavour. Cape gooseberries are prolific producers in Australian gardens and are excellent fresh, in jams, and in desserts.
tips: Harvest when the papery husk turns brown and the berry inside turns golden. Berries store for weeks in their husks. Self-seeds readily ‚Äî can become weedy. Plants can live 2‚Äì3 years in frost-free climates.

name: Lemon (Meyer)
description: The finest lemon for home gardens ‚Äî Meyer lemon produces sweeter, less acidic, thin-skinned fruit almost year-round and is the most compact and forgiving of all citrus trees. Outstanding in containers.
tips: Always buy grafted trees ‚Äî they fruit earlier and are disease-resistant. Feed with a dedicated citrus fertiliser 3‚Äì4 times per year. Water deeply and infrequently rather than little and often. In pots, use premium potting mix and repot every 3 years. Protect from frost in cold climates.

name: Lime (Tahitian)
description: The most commonly grown lime in Australia, producing thin-skinned, seedless, juicy limes with a bright, clean acidity. Tahitian lime is more cold-tolerant than kaffir or key lime and fruits prolifically in most of Australia.
tips: Needs warmth and protection from frost. Harvest limes when they reach full size, even if still green ‚Äî colour is not an indicator of ripeness for limes. Feed with citrus fertiliser in spring, summer, and autumn.

name: Orange (Navel)
description: Australia's most popular eating orange, producing large, seedless, sweet fruit with a characteristic 'navel' dimple at the base. Washington Navel is the classic Australian winter orange, superb for eating and juicing.
tips: Needs a warm position sheltered from cold winds. Fruit can stay on the tree for months after ripening, extending the harvest window. Thin fruit after the natural 'June drop' to improve size. Feed twice yearly with citrus fertiliser.

name: Mandarin
description: Easy-to-peel, sweet, aromatic citrus that is beloved by children and adults alike. Varieties like Imperial and Honey Murcott produce abundantly in warm Australian climates and are excellent for containers.
tips: Imperial is excellent for cooler climates; Murcott is better in warm, coastal areas. Mandarins tend to alternate heavy and light crops ‚Äî thin fruit in heavy years for better sizing. One of the most compact citrus trees, ideal for smaller gardens and pots.

name: Cumquat
description: The smallest citrus fruit ‚Äî eaten whole, skin and all ‚Äî with a unique sweet skin and tart flesh. Cumquats are the most ornamental citrus tree, producing masses of small orange fruit that persist for months, and are ideal for containers.
tips: The most cold-tolerant citrus ‚Äî survives light frosts. Fruit persists on the tree for months, creating a stunning display. Excellent for marmalades and preserves. One of the best citrus choices for a small balcony or courtyard.

name: Apple (Dwarf)
description: Dwarf apple trees on dwarfing rootstock produce full-sized apples on compact trees ideal for small gardens and large containers. Most varieties need a cold winter chill for good fruiting and require cross-pollination.
tips: Plant 2 compatible varieties for cross-pollination. Low-chill varieties like Anna and Dorsett Golden suit warmer Australian climates. Thin fruit to 1 per cluster in November for better size and quality. Annual pruning in winter is essential for sustained productivity.

name: Peach (Dwarf)
description: Dwarf peach trees produce luscious, fragrant peaches on compact trees that are beautiful in flower and incredibly productive when happy. They need a cold winter to break dormancy and fruit well.
tips: Most peaches are self-fertile ‚Äî one tree is enough. Thin fruit heavily to 1 per 15 cm when small ‚Äî thinning is the single most important step for good fruit size. Prune each year after harvest to maintain an open vase shape. Low-chill varieties suit warmer climates.

name: Nectarine (Dwarf)
description: A smooth-skinned variant of peach with a bright, sweet-tart flavour. Nectarines are otherwise identical in growing requirements to peaches but are generally considered more susceptible to brown rot and disease.
tips: Care identical to peach. Choose disease-resistant varieties in humid areas. Fruit ripens slightly earlier than most peaches. The smooth skin means no fuzzy texture ‚Äî preferred by many for fresh eating. Thin fruit even more aggressively than peaches for best results.

name: Cherry (Dwarf)
description: Sweet and sour cherries on compact rootstocks, producing stunning spring blossom and jewel-like fruit in early summer. Cherries need significant winter chill and are best suited to cooler areas of Australia (Victoria, Tasmania, cool highlands).
tips: Most sweet cherries need a pollinator ‚Äî check compatibility before buying. Net before fruit colours ‚Äî birds will take every cherry otherwise. Sour (morello) cherries are self-fertile and more tolerant of warmer conditions. Water consistently as fruit swells to prevent cracking.

name: Pear (Dwarf)
description: Elegant deciduous trees producing fragrant, buttery fruit in autumn. Pears need a cold winter chill but are slightly more adaptable to warmer conditions than apples. Compact varieties do well in large containers.
tips: Most pears require cross-pollination. Harvest before fully ripe and ripen at room temperature ‚Äî pears are one of few fruits that ripen better off the tree. Williams and Josephine de Malines are popular low-chill varieties for warmer areas.

name: Fig
description: One of the most rewarding fruit trees for Australian gardens ‚Äî figs produce abundantly with minimal care, are drought-tolerant, and do exceptionally well in large containers. The two crops per year (breba and main) provide a long harvest season.
tips: Hardy and largely pest-free. Once established, figs actually fruit better with some drought stress. Do not overfeed with nitrogen ‚Äî it produces lush leaves but poor fruit. Prune in winter to maintain size. Container figs can be kept small by root restriction ‚Äî an advantage!

name: Olive
description: Extraordinarily long-lived trees with beautiful silver-grey foliage, producing olives for table or pressing into oil. Olives need a cold winter to set fruit but are extremely drought-tolerant once established and long-lived in containers.
tips: Plant at least 2 varieties for reliable cross-pollination. Olives for eating must be cured to remove bitterness ‚Äî a multi-week process. For oil, you need significant quantities of fruit. Prune to open the canopy and let light in. Very long-lived in large containers.

name: Avocado (Dwarf)
description: Compact avocado varieties like Wurtz (also called 'Little Cado') produce full-sized fruit on trees suitable for large pots or small gardens. Avocados need a tropical to warm-temperate climate and are sensitive to frost and waterlogging.
tips: Buy a named grafted variety ‚Äî growing from a seed gives a plant that may never fruit. Needs excellent drainage ‚Äî avocados are extremely susceptible to Phytophthora root rot. Plant Wurtz (Type A) with a Type B pollinator for best fruit set. Best suited to QLD, NSW coast, WA coast.

name: Pomegranate
description: A beautiful ornamental and edible tree or large shrub producing large, jewel-red fruit filled with sweet-tart arils packed with antioxidants. Pomegranates thrive in hot, dry Australian summers and are surprisingly cold-tolerant.
tips: Extremely tolerant of heat, drought, and poor soil once established. Harvest when skin cracks slightly or sounds hollow when tapped ‚Äî do not wait for skin to soften (it hardens as it matures). Store whole fruit in a cool, dry place for months.

name: Feijoa
description: An underrated South American fruit with a complex tropical-minty flavour beloved in New Zealand and increasingly popular in Australia. Feijoas are highly ornamental with silver-green leaves and edible crimson-petalled flowers.
tips: Plant 2 varieties for cross-pollination for heavier crops (Unique is one self-fertile variety). Harvest when fruit falls naturally or yields to gentle pressure. Eat quickly ‚Äî feijoas ripen fast and don't store long. Flowers are edible and delicious in salads.

name: Mulberry (Dwarf)
description: Extraordinarily productive deciduous trees producing abundant, dark, sweet-tart berries in summer. Dwarf mulberry varieties are perfect for pots and small gardens. Berries stain heavily but the flavour is absolutely worth it.
tips: Harvest by spreading a sheet under the tree and gently shaking ‚Äî ripe berries fall easily. Wear old clothes ‚Äî the juice stains permanently. Black mulberry (Morus nigra) has the richest flavour. Harvest frequently in peak season to avoid fruit fly.

name: Finger Lime
description: An iconic Australian native citrus producing elongated fruit filled with tiny, caviar-like pearls of intensely tart citrus juice. Finger limes are highly sought after by chefs and are a wonderful conversation-starter in any garden.
tips: Buy from a specialist nursery ‚Äî thorny plants with slow early growth. Thrives in slightly acidic, well-drained soil. Fruit is ripe when it changes colour and falls easily. Can be thorny ‚Äî wear gloves when harvesting. Excellent grafted onto Flying Dragon rootstock for compact size.

name: Lemon Myrtle
description: Australia's most intensely lemon-scented plant ‚Äî more powerfully lemony than any lemon or lemon herb. The leaves are used fresh or dried in teas, baked goods, seafood, and sauces. A beautiful native rainforest tree suited to warm, humid climates.
tips: Keep moist and protected from frost. Clip regularly to keep compact in containers. Harvest leaves as needed ‚Äî they dry beautifully for long-term storage. Also produces attractive white flowers. Best in Queensland and northern NSW; needs protection in cooler areas.

name: Banana (Dwarf)
description: Dwarf Cavendish and other compact banana varieties produce full-sized fruit on plants under 2 m ‚Äî manageable in a large pot or warm backyard. Bananas grow fast in tropical and subtropical Australia.
tips: Buy suckers from a garden centre or local grower. Feed heavily and keep well watered ‚Äî bananas are hungry, thirsty plants. A single plant flowers and fruits once then dies ‚Äî but produces 'pups' (suckers) to replace it. In temperate areas, grow in a warm, sheltered spot or large pot you can move.

name: Papaya
description: A fast-growing tropical tree producing large, sweet, orange-fleshed fruit rich in vitamins A and C. Papayas are one of the fastest fruit trees to produce from seed ‚Äî often fruiting within 12 months ‚Äî and thrive in tropical and subtropical Australia.
tips: Grow several plants to ensure at least one is female (or hermaphrodite ‚Äî which self-pollinates). Papaya trees are short-lived ‚Äî replace every 3‚Äì4 years for consistent productivity. Grows best in frost-free tropical and subtropical climates (QLD, Top End, coastal WA).

name: Alfalfa Sprouts
description: Delicate, mild, nutritious sprouts grown in jars on your kitchen bench in just 5‚Äì7 days. Alfalfa sprouts require no soil, no light (until the final day), and no special equipment ‚Äî just a jar, some muslin, and water.
tips: Soak seeds for 8 hours, then rinse and drain twice daily. Move to indirect light on day 4‚Äì5 to green up. Refrigerate and eat within 3‚Äì4 days. One tablespoon of seeds yields about a full jar of sprouts.

name: Sunflower Microgreens
description: Large, juicy microgreens with a sweet, nutty flavour and satisfying crunch. Sunflower microgreens are among the most popular and productive microgreens ‚Äî fast-growing, flavourful, and packed with nutrition.
tips: Use hulled or unhulled seeds ‚Äî hulled are less messy. Soak seeds for 8 hours before sowing. Cover with blackout lid for first 3‚Äì4 days, then expose to light. Harvest by cutting just above soil level when cotyledons (seed leaves) are fully open.

name: Pea Shoots
description: Tender, sweet pea tendrils and young leaves with a delicate fresh pea flavour. Pea shoots are one of the most delicious microgreens ‚Äî excellent in salads, stir-fries, and as a garnish for almost any dish.
tips: Soak peas overnight before sowing. Sow densely in trays of seed-raising mix, 2 cm deep. Harvest at 10‚Äì15 cm by cutting above the soil. The tray will often regrow for a second cut. Field peas, snow peas, or sugar snap pea seeds all work equally well.

name: Radish Microgreens
description: Vivid pink-stemmed microgreens with a bright, peppery radish flavour and attractive colour. One of the fastest and most striking microgreens ‚Äî ready in under 10 days and wonderful in salads and sandwiches.
tips: One of the easiest and most reliable microgreens. Keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Cover for first 3 days then expose to light. Harvest when cotyledons are fully open. Mix varieties (red, white, purple radish) for a colourful microgreen blend.

name: Broccoli Microgreens
description: One of the most nutritionally dense foods available ‚Äî broccoli microgreens contain exceptionally high levels of sulforaphane, a powerful cancer-fighting compound. Mild, fresh flavour with a subtle broccoli note.
tips: Scatter seed densely and press gently into moist seed-raising mix. Cover for 3 days then move to indirect light. Harvest when first true leaves appear (about day 7‚Äì10). Eat raw to preserve sulforaphane content.

name: Wheatgrass
description: Young wheat shoots harvested before the jointing stage and juiced or blended. Wheatgrass is celebrated for its extremely high chlorophyll, vitamin, and mineral content. Grows rapidly and can be cut multiple times.
tips: Use hard wheat berries (not soft wheat flour wheat). Soak overnight then sow densely on 3‚Äì4 cm of potting mix. Keep covered for 2 days. Harvest at 15‚Äì20 cm by cutting with scissors just above soil level. Allow to regrow for a second or third cut.

name: Sorrel
description: A tangy, lemony perennial leaf vegetable used in French soups, sauces, and salads. Sorrel grows from the same clump for years and is one of the first plants to produce leaves in late winter, making it invaluable in the winter garden.
tips: Remove flower stalks as they appear to keep the plant producing leaves. Older leaves become more sour ‚Äî use smaller, younger leaves in salads. High in oxalic acid ‚Äî not suitable in large quantities for those with kidney issues.

name: Mung Bean Sprouts
description: The classic Asian sprout used in stir-fries, soups, and spring rolls. Mung bean sprouts are incredibly easy to grow in a jar in 4‚Äì5 days and are one of the most widely consumed sprouts in the world.
tips: Soak whole mung beans for 8‚Äì12 hours. Keep in a jar with a mesh lid, draining and rinsing twice daily. Keep in a warm, dark cupboard for maximum crunch. Rinse very well before eating. Can also be grown in soil as a microgreen for longer shoots.
common_problems: Slimy sprouts if not drained properly

name: Ginger
description: A tropical rhizome with zingy, pungent flavour essential in Asian, Indian, and Middle Eastern cooking as well as in teas and confectionery. Ginger grows beautifully in pots in warm to tropical parts of Australia.
tips: Plant fresh rhizomes from the supermarket or nursery with 'eyes' pointing up. Harvest young 'green ginger' at 4 months for mild flavour, or wait until tops die back for mature, pungent rhizomes. Keep warm and consistently moist throughout growing season. Avoid direct midday sun.

name: Turmeric
description: The golden spice of Indian cooking and Ayurvedic medicine, grown from rhizomes for its intensely coloured, mildly earthy-peppery fresh root. Turmeric is ornamental with large tropical leaves and grows well in pots in warm climates.
tips: Care identical to ginger. Fresh turmeric is far superior to dried powder ‚Äî peel and grate or slice directly into curries and smoothies. WARNING: the yellow pigment stains everything it touches, including hands, clothes, and bench surfaces. Wear gloves when handling.

name: Jerusalem Artichoke
description: A North American perennial producing knobbly, sweet tubers with a nutty flavour excellent roasted, pureed, or in soups. The plants grow tall with cheerful yellow flowers but can be very invasive ‚Äî every tiny piece of tuber left in the soil regrows.
tips: Plant tubers purchased from a supermarket or nursery. Contain their spread ‚Äî plant in a raised bed with a solid barrier or in a large pot. Harvest after tops die down in autumn/winter. Start small ‚Äî a patch of 5‚Äì6 plants provides an abundance. Not related to Jerusalem or artichokes!
